column4: hi, i have a question: can ubuntu remove (uninstall) packages that are no longer needed, as in dependencies that are not needed anymore etc.. ?
yes, you can use deborphan for that
but it's not something that's done automatically ?
only if you use aptitude for package management.  apt-get and synaptic don't remove obsolete dependencies automatically
only if you use aptitude for installation and removal
isn't that the default on ubuntu ?
well no, it's one of many front-ends to apt, Synaptic and apt-get are more popular
Ubuntu is pretty good (i have a mac mini) but it's the only Linux distro i've tried
if it's feasible it's generally the best way.  However the upgrade is usually fine.
well with a fresh install you are always starting from a known state
no, if it installed without any force- options it should be fine
ok thanks. i assume the only down side then is that i won't get updates for that package ?
no, unless it appears in your repositories later :)
that was my next question, what happens if it appears in the repo later ?
if it's a later version in the repo it will offer to upgrade
